revision.author: jkeffer
revision.comment: Match info in other topics and add subject affinities

description.p: A container element for information on a content set. A content set is a collection of topic sets. To define a content set, you list the configuration files for each topic set in the content set using a /content-set/topic-sets/topic-set element.

To build a full content set, you simply run the spfe build tool with a configuration file that contains a content-set element directly (not via inclusion). The build tool will then run whichever build command you have specified on all the topic sets in the content set, as well as creating the files that belong to the content set as a whole.
An ID for the content set. This value is used as the name of a directory containing the content set build inside the build directory.
Specifies the condition tokens that will be applied to this content set by the resolve step.
An identifier for the docset.

restriction.p: The content-set-id is used to form paths in the output, so it must be a permitted directory name on all output media.

description.p: Designates one topic set as the home topic set for the content set. The home topic set becomes the home for the content set as a whole. In many cases, a home topic set will consist of a single topic, with the name index, which will become the home page of the content set. However, you can include as many topics as you like in the home topic set. If you only have one topic set in your content set, you should designate it as the home topic set.

restriction.p: The value must match the topic set id of one topic set in the content set. Topic set IDs are defined in /topic-set/topic-set-id.

description.p: Specifies the types of messages that will be generated by the build. Possible value are info, and warning.
A container element for a list of object sets that are to be built for this content set.

note.title: Object sets not included in output by default
note.p: Note that including an object set in a content set does not mean that those objects will automatically become part of the output. Objects become part of the output when they are included in topics, either through direct inclusion or via soft linking. If not topic includes an object, it will not be part of the output. Choosing which object sets to include in the build is one way to manage reuse or create variant content.

description.p: A container element for the reference to an object set configuration file.

fragment.p: The href of a file containing .

description.p: The object set id of a object set to be included in the current content set. What does this correlate with?
A container element for a list of object types that are included in a content set.
A container element for a reference to an object type configuration file.
The name of an object type contained in an object type configuration file.

restriction.p: This value must match the name declared in the object type configuration file pointed to by the href setting.

description.p: The name of the other configuration setting.
A container element for a list of output formats supported by the content set build.
An output format supported by the content set build.
The name of an output format.
A container element for the configuration settings related to presentation types.
A container element for the setting related to a particular presentation type.
A location to copy the output of the presentation stage to. Likely to be deprecated.

The name of a presentation type to be built for this content set. The name is used in the configuration of an output format to indicate which presentation type the output format is to use as input. This is configured in /output-format/presentation-type.

fragment.p: A container element for a list of string elements that define strings used by the tools or in content. This setting defines strings for . To define strings for , use .
Defines a string and gives it an ID. Strings may be used by both the build tools and in content.

The ID of the string. The string id is used to insert the string into a script or a piece of content. The markup used to insert a string may vary from one document type to another. In EPPO-Simple, the string-ref element is used.

description.p: A container for a list of subject types used in the content set. Subject types are the classification of subjects referred to by subject affinity markup and used to index topics. The subject type listing is used to provide aliases for the subject types when the name of the subject types is displayed in the output. For example, in the SPFE content, SPFE configuration settings are marked up using the config-setting element. config-setting is thus a subject type in this content set. However, when the output explicitly refers to a configuration setting (for instance, in a list page) the string Configuration setting is used in the singular and Configuration settings is used in the plural. These string are generated based on the value of the /content-set/subject-types/subject-type/aliases/singular and /content-set/subject-types/subject-type/aliases/plural settings for the config-setting subject type, as defined in the configuration file for this content set.
A container for a subject type listing.
A container for a pair of subject type aliases.
The plural version of a subject type alias.
The singular version of a subject type alias.
The id of a subject type. This is identical to an item in the list of subject affinity values used in the topic index.
The title of the content set.
A container element for the list of topic sets in a content set.
The path to a topic set configuration file for a topic set to be included in the content set.
The topic set id of the included topic set, it should normally match the /topic-set/topic-set-id element in the topic set's configuration file.

restriction.p: The topic-set-id is used to form file names and should be a valid file name on all target operating systems.

description.p: A container element for configuration information on the work in progress site.
A container for login information for FTP access to the work in progress site.
The ftp password for the work in progress site.
The URL of the ftp login to the work in progress site.
The user name for logging in to the work in progress site.
The file path to the root of the work in progress site.
The URL of the work in progress site.
The root element of a file type configuration file.
The name of a file type. What is this used for?

fragment.p: The name of the type that this script produces./file-type/scripts/format/@type

Container element for a list of link scripts. The link scripts are responsible for generating links from one topic to another. They do this by reading the topic catalog to find suitable topics to link to.

description.p: The name of an other script type.
The root element of an object set configuration file.
The id of an object set described by a object set configuration file.How is this used?
A container of a list of object types in an object set.
A container element for a list of object type configuration files that describe the object types in this object set.
The name of an object type to be included in this object set. What does this value match with?
A container element for a list of source files for the objects in this object set.
A container element for a list of authored content files to be included in this object set.
The name of an other script type.
A container element for the configuration of an object type.
The name of the object type defined by this configuration file. How is this used?
Objects can also be indexed. The indexes can be use to resolve subject affinities to objects, rahter than having authors insert objects explicitly into topics.

fragment.p: Container element for a list of extraction scripts. The extract scripts are responsible for extracting data from external sources, which may then be used to generate objects for inclusion in your content set. For example, you might use a extract script to create a chart from a set of data in a database.
A container element for a list of structures used by this .
A container element that holds the name and href of a structure configuration file for a structure to be included in this .

description.p: The name of a structure used by this object type. How it is used?
A container element for the configuration of an output type.
The name of the output format.

Specifies the presentation type used by an output format. This is used to enable the SPFE build system to select the right set of presentation files to feed to the format scripts for this output format.

restriction.p: This value must match the value of a presentation type that is part of the build for each topic set. The presentation types available in the topic set build are specified by the setting /topic-set/presentation-types/presentation-type.

description.p: Output types cannot be indexed and it is unlikely that an output type would want to change the way content is indexed. However, this setting lets you contribute an output-type-specific link catalog script to the build.

Container element for a list of extraction scripts. It is unlikely that an output type will want to contribute a script to the extraction process, and may indicate a poor separation of concerns in your architecture. However, if you do want to extract content different for a particular output format, this setting allows you to specify the appropriate extract script component.
A list of support files, such as JavaScript file or CSS files used by the output format. These are coppied to the output directory by the build.

local-strings.string: support files (style sheets, script file, etc.)

description.p: The root element of a presentation type configuration file.
The name of a presentation type.
A container elements for a list of scripts for a particular presentation type.
A container for the configuration of a present script for this presentation type.
A container element for the configuration of a topic type for this presentation type.
A container element for the configuration of scripts used for processing a particular topic type for this presentation type.
The name of the topic type to be configured for this presentation type.
A container element for a list of scripts used for processing this topic type for this presentation type.
A container for the configuration of a present script for this topic type for this presentation type.
A container element for the configuration of a structure.
The name of the structure defined by this structure configuration file. How it is used?
The name of an other script type.
Structures are recursive. That is, a structure may contain other structures.
The name of a structure used by this structure. How it is used?
A container element for the configuration of a topic set.
Specifies the condition tokens that will be applied to this topic set by the resolve process.

Specifies the subject scope tokens to be applied to all subjects in all topics in the build by default. Effectively, specifying this setting applies scope to subjects that do not specify a scope. Subject affinities that declare their own scope are not affected by this setting.

Specifies the topic scope tokens to be applied to all topics in the build by default. Effectively, specifying this setting applies scope to topics that do not specify a scope. Topics that declare their own scope are not affected by this setting.
A container element for a list of object types included in a topic set.
The list of object types is used to locate the configuration file for each object type, which in turn lists the scripts used to process objects of this type.

restriction.p: Every object type occurring in the topic set must be listed here. If an unlisted object type is included, an error will occur at the synthesis stage of the build when the synthesis scripts will be unable to find templates to process the object type.

description.p: An item in the list of the object types included in a topic set. The topic type is identified by its XML name (name) of the XML document that describes the individual object (for instance, a graphic record file, for a standard graphic), and the URL of its configuration file (href).

restriction.p: The setting must contain the location of a valid object type configuration file.

description.p: The name of an object type to be included in this topic set.

fragment.p: You can use the element to add additional configuration settings to be used by your scripts of build files.

description.p: The name of the other configuration setting.

A container for a list of output formats to be created for the topic set. You should specify an output format for each of the output formats you want the SPFE build to create for a topic set. The scripts for an output format are contained in a /topic-type/scripts/format element with a name attribute that matches the name of the format type, as specified in /topic-set/output-formats/output-format/name.
A container for the name of a output format.

The name of an output format. The name forms part of the path to the output-format build directory, to separate it from other output format builds. It is also used to select the format scrips used to create the output format..

A container element for a list of presentation types to be generated for a topic set. A presentation type is a way of presenting content for use in a particular class of media (online vs. paper, top-down vs. bottom-up, etc.). A presentation type is expressed as a presentation schema. Each output format is written to format a particular presentation type. Therefore, you must ensure that there is an appropriate presentation type specified for each of the output formats you specify for a topic type. The output format configuration specifies the presentation format that it uses in the setting /output-format/presentation-type. In order to build a presentation of the specified type, there must be a set of presentation scripts for this presentation type for each topic type included in the topic set. The scripts for a presentation type are contained in a /topic-type/scripts/present element with a type attribute that matches the name of the presentation type, as specified in /topic-set/presentation-types/presentation-type.
The name of a presentation type.

restriction.p: An error will result if there is no presentation type specified for any output format used for the topic type. The presentation type used by an output format is specified in the setting /output-format/presentation-type.

description.p: A container element for the list of sources to be included in a topic set. Sources include authored content file, graphics, sources to extract content from, and other.

fragment.p: A container element for a list of file selectors that select the to include in the build.

description.p: Authored content includes all textual sources created by authors. It includes topics, text objects, fragments, strings (other than those defined in the configuration files), and content to be merged with extracted content.

fragment.p: A glob expression indicating which to include in the build.

description.p: The name of the type of other source.

The topic-set-id element specifies the identifier for the current topic set. This identifier can be used to create a reference to the topic set. It is also used to create file and directory names, so it should be a value that is a valid file name (minus the extension) on all target operating systems.

fragment.p: Used in determining the link priority of a topic when there is more than one possible target for a link. The overall link priority of a topic is obtained by adding its topic set link priority to its topic type link priority, specified by .

description.p: This setting enables you to assign a type string to a topic set.
A container element for a list of topic types included in a topic set.

The list of topic types is used to locate the configuration file for each topic type, which in turn lists the scripts used to process topics of this type. The list is also used to determine the topic type order for a topic set, which determines the order in which topic types are listed in a generated table of contents.

restriction.p: Every topic type occurring in the topic set must be listed here. If an unlisted topic type is included, an error will occur at the synthesis stage of the build when the synthesis scripts will be unable to find templates to process the topic type.

Note that it is possible to write a resolve script that attempts to process an unrecognized topic type. In this case, the error described above may not occur. This is unwise, however, since such a script cannot be guaranteed to correctly interpret all the structure of an unknown type, which may result in unanticipated effects in the output.

description.p: An item in the list of the topic types included in a topic set. The topic type is identified by its name (name) and the URL of its configuration file (href).

restriction.p: The setting must contain the location of a valid topic type configuration file.

description.p: The name of a topic type to be included in this topic set.
A container element for the configuration of a topic type.

A container element for a pair or topic type aliases, singular and plural. Topic types in SPFE are formally identified by the namespace URI of the topic schema. In some cases, however, we need to display the topic type to the user. For this purpose we need a user-friendly alias for the topic type.

fragment.p: A version of the topic type alias. For instance, in the SPFE documentation, the alias for the topic type formally identified as http://spfeopentoolkit.org/ns/spfe-docs is . The namespace alias configuration for this looks like this:

description.p: A container element for a list of file types included in this topic set.
A container element for the configuration of a file type included in this topic set.
The name of the file type to be included in this topic type.
The name of this topic type.

fragment.p: A container for the list of scripts to be used to process at each step of the build process. Each build script for each step should be written to use the standard SPFE interface for a script. Listing the full path of the script for each step in this list will then cause that script to be called at the appropriate step of the build process.

You may specify more than one script for each stage. The build will create a temporary script file that includes each of the scripts listed for each stage. One, and only one, of the included scripts must have a template named "main", which the build rule will call as the initial template (unless you have overridden the build rule for this step in your custom build file.

This mechanism for building the final script by including a list of specified scripts allows you to customize the build for each topic set while maintaining a high degree of modularity and reuse in your script collections. A typical way to use this mechanism would be to include a separate script at the presentation stage for each of the topic types included in the build. This mechanism does not prevent you from including one script file in another in the normal way, it just gives you a more flexible way of managing modular script files and assembling the right set for each topic set.

Container element for a list of catalog scripts. The link catalog script is responsible for creating a catalog of all the link targets in a topic set. For topics types whose resolve scripts produce a standard synthesis header with index terms embedded, the standard EPPO-simple catalog script can be used. In most cases it will be preferable to create the index header at the resolve stage rather than to produce a non-standard synthesis and then write your own link catalog script. However, that option is available and you can specify the use of your own catalog script using this setting.

description.p: Container element for a list of extraction scripts. The extract scripts are responsible for extracting content from external sources, which may then be combined with authored content to form complete topics.

fragment.p: The full path to script file.

Specifies the location of the stylesheet file to be included. You may specify either a relative or absolute local path, or a URL. If a URL is used, the SPFE build will use any XML catalogs available to it to resolve the location of the script. For the sake of portability, you should use a URL whenever possible. If it is not possible to use a URL, use a relative path wherever possible.

Instructs the SPFE build to remap the namespace declarations in an included script file. Instances of an xmlns namespace declaration or a xpath-default-namespace declaration with the namespace URI specified by from are changed to the namespace URI specified by to. A separate copy of the imported stylesheet will be included for each namespace remapping found for all topic types in a topic set. This allows you to borrow the same topic structures and scripts in several topic types and have them all processed using their correct namespaces.
The namespace URI to be matched in the included stylesheet. It will be replaced by the namespace URI specified by to.
The namespace URI to be used to replace the namespace URI specified by from in an included stylesheet.
A container for a list of script components for formatting a topic set in HTML.

A container for a list of image-list scripts. Unless you have introduced custom image handling into your system, the default image handling script should work for all topic types. The image-list script is part of the format step. It generates a list of all the graphics included in the presentation so that the build scripts can copy those graphics to the appropriate location in the output.
Container element for a list of merge scripts. The merge scripts are responsible for combining content from two or more sources to create topics.
A container for a named list of scripts to perform an additional step that is not part of the normal SPFE build sequence.
The name of the extra step.

description.p: The full path of a script that is part of the extra step.

fragment.p: A container for a list of present script components for building a presentation of the topic set. Usually there will be one script for the topic set as a whole and one script for each topic type in the script.

Container element for a list of resolve script components for . The resolve scripts are responsible for assembling a set of topics in which all names are fully resolved and all conditions and inclusions have been applied. Script components contribute the handling of different elements to the resolve script.
A container for a list of scripts for creating a table of contents file for the topic set.

description.p: The name of a structure used by this object type. How it is used?

The title of a topic set is normally defined in the topic set configuration file in the setting /topic-set/title. However, the content set configuration file can override the title specified in the topic set configuration by defining this setting.
The title of this topic set. This value can be overridden by the importing content set configuration file in the setting /content-set/topic-sets/topic-set/title.

Establishes a set of topic set groups for the content set. You can define groups and place topic sets into those groups, which forms the basis of a table of contents for the content set, or for any other way of presenting groups of topic sets. Groups can be defined hierarchically by nesting one group definition inside another. To place a topic set in a group, use the setting /content-set/topic-sets/topic-set/group.
Defines a topic set group. The definition consists of the name of the group and the definition of any subgroups.
The name of a topic set group. The use that the publishing process makes of this name is up to the developer, but it is assumed to be the group name as it will appear in the published content.

You can define topic set groups recursively to form a hierarchy. You can define groups within groups to whatever level of depth you wish. However, publishing processes may have limits on how many level of topic set grouping they can support. It should be considered the responsibility of the publishing process to raise an error if it is presented with more levels of grouping than it expects.

Assigns a topic set to a topic set group in the context of this content set. Note that the assignment of topic sets to groups is a feature of the content set configuration, not an intrinsic property of the topic set itself. A topic set can be assigned to different topic set groups in different content set configurations.
